verses.latin: Diligite iustitiam, qui judicatis terram : sentite de Domino in bonitate, et in simplicitate cordis quaerite illum.
verses.english: Love justice, all you who are judges of the earth. Think of the Lord with goodness, and seek Him with a simple heart.

verses.latin: Quoniam invenitur ab his qui non tentant illum : et apparet eis qui fidem habent in illum.
verses.english: He is found by those who do not test Him, and He appears to those who have faith in Him.

verses.latin: Perversae enim cogitationes separant a Deo : probata autem virtus corripit insipientis.
verses.english: Perverse thoughts separate one from God, but virtue corrects those who are unwise.

verses.latin: Quoniam in malevolam animam non introibit sapientia, nec habitabit in corpore subdito peccatis.
verses.english: For wisdom will not enter into a malevolent soul, nor dwell in a body subject to sins.

verses.latin: Spiritus enim sanctus disciplinae effugiet fictum, et auferet se a cogitationibus quae sunt sine intellectu, et a reprobatione reprobabitur.
verses.english: The Holy Spirit of discipline will flee from the false, and will depart from thoughts that are without understanding, and will be rejected by the reprobate.

verses.latin: Sapi entia est enim spiritus amicus hominis, et non dimittet impium a verbis labiorum ejus : quoniam Deus testis est renum ejus, et exactor cordis illius, et inspector linguarum ejus.
verses.english: Wisdom is a friend to man, and will not leave the wicked because of the words of his lips, for God is the witness of his conscience, the examiner of his heart, and the observer of his tongue.

verses.latin: Quoniam Dominus spiritus sapientiae : et qui facit omnia novit, et qui scit omnia, ipse novit eam, et qui excogitavit eam, investigavit eam.
verses.english: For the Lord is the spirit of wisdom, and He knows all things, and He who knows all things, knows wisdom, and He who has created wisdom, has investigated wisdom.

verses.latin: Diligit enim qui habitat cum sapientia.
verses.english: For He loves those who dwell with wisdom.

verses.latin: Pulchrior est enim sole, et super omnem stellarum dispositionem : luci comparata invenitur prior.
verses.english: For she is more beautiful than the sun, and above all the arrangement of the stars: being compared to light, she is found to be first.

verses.latin: Post hanc, illi qui sunt, nox sequitur, malitia, et mors :
verses.english: After this, night, malice, and death follow.

verses.latin: Qui autem in illa manent, non timebunt, sed requiescent cum illa.
verses.english: But those who remain in her will not fear, but will rest with her.

verses.latin: Quoniam mors, et vita in manu ejus : et bona voluntas illi placita est.
verses.english: For death and life are in her hand, and good will is pleasing to her.

verses.latin: Qui displicet illi, ipse fit per odium, et nequitia, et peccatis.
verses.english: He who displeases her, becomes so through hatred, wickedness, and sins.

verses.latin: Aliquando enim simul cum impiis est : sed non credetur malitia.
verses.english: For sometimes she is with the wicked, but wickedness will not be believed.

verses.latin: Sperans enim vanitatem, generat ventum : et sequens aves volantes, persequitur stultitiam.
verses.english: For he who hopes in vanity generates the wind, and he who follows flying birds, pursues foolishness.

verses.latin: Recedit enim a Domino, et a sapientia spiritus ejus.
verses.english: For he departs from the Lord and from the wisdom of His Spirit.

verses.latin: Qui enim impii sunt, et quae sunt Dei, et quae audiunt, non bene locuntur, et qui sunt sine disciplina, ad eam non possunt custodire.
verses.english: For the wicked do not speak well of what belongs to God, and those who are without discipline cannot keep her.

verses.latin: Quoniam ab eo divisus est spiritus sanctus, et recessit a cogitationibus illorum.
verses.english: For the Holy Spirit is divided from them, and has departed from their thoughts.

verses.latin: Sapientia enim est spiritus amabilis : et non mitigabit maledicum a labiis suis, quoniam Deus testis est renum ejus, et exactor cordis illius, et inspector linguarum ejus.
verses.english: For wisdom is a loving spirit, and will not acquit the blasphemer from his lips, for God is the witness of his conscience, and the examiner of his heart, and the observer of his tongue.

verses.latin: Cogitaverunt enim amentes, non recte: cogitationes illorum vanæ, et errantes sensus illorum.
verses.english: Fools think wrongly. Their thoughts are empty and confused.

verses.latin: Dicentes: Vita nostra brevis et tædiosa, et non est curæ hominis mors, et non est agnitus qui de inferis rediit.
verses.english: They say, “Our life is short and full of sorrows, and there is no cure for death, and no one returns from the grave.”

verses.latin: Casus enim natus est nos, et post hoc non erit, quoniam signatum est vinculo: et nemo redit.
verses.english: We were born by chance, and after this, there will be nothing. Death is like a final seal: no one can come back.

verses.latin: Quoniam ex nihilo nati sumus, et post hoc erimus tamquam non fuerimus: quoniam fumus est flatus in naribus nostris, et sermo scintilla ad motum cordis nostri.
verses.english: We came from nothing and will return to nothing. Our breath is like smoke in our nostrils, and our thoughts are like a spark that leaps in our hearts.

verses.latin: Qua extincta cinerem vertetur corpus, et spiritus dissipabitur tamquam mollis aer.
verses.english: When the body is extinguished, it will turn to ashes, and the spirit will vanish like soft air.

verses.latin: Et nomen nostrum obliviscetur in tempore, et nemo memoriam operum nostrorum habebit.
verses.english: In time, our name will be forgotten, and no one will remember our deeds.

verses.latin: Transit enim tamquam umbra, et non est reversio ejus: et signatum est, ut nullus revertatur.
verses.english: We pass like a shadow and cannot return. It is sealed: no one can return.

verses.latin: Venite ergo, et fruamur bonis quæ sunt: et utamur creaturæ, tamquam in juventute.
verses.english: Come, then, let us enjoy the good things that are here. Let us enjoy the pleasures of youth.

verses.latin: Vino pretioso et unguentis nos inpleamus, et non prætereat nos flos temporis.
verses.english: Let us fill ourselves with costly wine and perfumes, and let the flowers of spring pass us by.

verses.latin: Coronemus nos rosis antequam marcescant: et non sit ulla prati nostri, quod non pertranseat luxuriæ.
verses.english: Let us crown ourselves with roses before they wither. Let none of us be without our share of our luxury.

verses.latin: Sit potestas nostra justitiæ: quoniam quod debile est, inutile est.
verses.english: Let us have power over the just; for that which is weak is useless.

verses.latin: Opprimamus pauperem justum, et non parcamus viduæ, nec senis revereamur canos senectutis.
verses.english: Let us oppress the poor and the just, and let us not spare the widow. Let us show no respect for the gray hairs of the old.

verses.latin: Sit fortitudo nostra lex justitiæ: quod enim debile est, probatur inutile.
verses.english: Let our strength be our law of justice, for the weak are shown to be useless.

verses.latin: Insidiemur ergo justo, quoniam inutilis est nobis, et contrarius est operibus nostris, et exprobrat nobis peccata vitæ nostræ.
verses.english: So let us lay traps for the just, because they are of no use to us, and they are against our deeds. They condemn us for the sins of our life.

verses.latin: Profitetur se scientiam Dei habere, et filium Dei se nominat.
verses.english: They claim to have knowledge of God and call themselves the children of God.

verses.latin: Factus est nobis in contradictionem cogitationum nostrarum: et gravis est nobis etiam ad videndum.
verses.english: They are a rebuke to our thoughts, and just to look at them is a burden to us.

verses.latin: Vita enim illius non similis est aliis, et diversæ sunt viæ illius.
verses.english: Their life is not like that of others, and their ways are different.

verses.latin: Estimati sumus ab illis tamquam nummi adulterini, et abstinent se a viis nostris tamquam a sordes.
verses.english: We are regarded as counterfeit coins, and they avoid our ways as if they were unclean.

verses.latin: Finem justi probant beati, et gloriantur in Deum patrem.
verses.english: They consider the end of the just to be blessed, and they boast of God as their father.

verses.latin: Videamus ergo si sermones illius veri sunt: et tentemus quæ ventura sunt illi.
verses.english: Let us see, then, if their words are true. Let us test what will happen to them.

verses.latin: Si enim est justus Dei filius, suscipiet illum, et liberabit eum de manibus inimicorum.
verses.english: If the just one is truly the Son of God, God will help him and deliver him from the hands of his enemies.

verses.latin: Contumelia et tormentis examinemus eum, ut sciamus modestiam illius, et probemus patientiam illius.
verses.english: Let us test him with insult and torture, so that we can understand his gentleness and know his patience.

verses.latin: Morte turpissima condemnemus eum: erit enim ei respectus ex sermonibus suis.
verses.english: Let us condemn him to a most shameful death, for he will be protected, as he claims, by his own words.

verses.latin: Ista cogitaverunt, et erraverunt: excæcati sunt enim malitia eorum.
verses.english: This is what they thought, and they were wrong, for their wickedness blinded them.

verses.latin: Et nescierunt sacramenta Dei, nec mercedem justitiæ putaverunt, nec præmium animarum sanctarum.
verses.english: They did not know the mysteries of God, nor did they think that justice would be rewarded or that the souls of the saints would be recompensed.

verses.latin: Quoniam Deus creavit hominem inexterminabilem, et imaginem similitudinis suæ fecit illum.
verses.english: For God created man to be imperishable, and He made him in the image of his own likeness.

verses.latin: Invidia autem diaboli mors introivit in orbem terrarum:
verses.english: By the devil’s envy, death entered the world,

verses.latin: imitantur autem illum qui sunt ex illius parte.
verses.english: and those who belong to him imitate him.

verses.latin: Iustorum animae in manu Dei sunt, et non tanget illos tormentum malitiae.
verses.english: The souls of the just are in the hand of God, and torment will not touch them.

verses.latin: Visi sunt oculis insipientium mori, et aestimata est mors illorum plagium,
verses.english: Fools thought the just were dead, and they considered their death a punishment,

verses.latin: et iter illorum exitium;
verses.english: and their departure an utter destruction;

verses.latin: et sunt in pace.
verses.english: but they are at peace.

verses.latin: Et si coram hominibus tormenta passi sunt, spes illorum immortalitatis plena.
verses.english: And though in the sight of men they suffered torments, their hope is full of immortality.

verses.latin: In paucis vexati, in multis bene beati: quoniam Deus probavit illos,
verses.english: Having been punished in a few things, they will receive many blessings, for God tested them,

verses.latin: et invenit illos dignos se.
verses.english: and found them worthy of Himself.

verses.latin: Tamquam aurum in fornace probavit illos, et quasi holocausto hostiae suscepit illos.
verses.english: As gold in the furnace, He has tried them, and as a holocaust offering, He received them.

verses.latin: Et in tempore visitationis illorum resplendebunt, et sicut scintillae in arundineto discurrent.
verses.english: And in the time of their visitation they shall shine, and shall run to and fro as sparks among the reeds.

verses.latin: Judicabunt nationes, et dominabuntur populis, et regnabit Dominus illorum in perpetuum.
verses.english: They shall judge the nations, and rule over the peoples, and the Lord will reign over them forever.

verses.latin: Qui confidunt in illum, intellegent veritatem, et qui fideles sunt in dilectione, permanebunt in illo: quoniam gratia et pax electis ejus.
verses.english: Those who trust in Him will understand the truth, and those who are faithful in love will abide in Him; for grace and peace is to His elect.

verses.latin: Impii autem in cogitationibus suis correptionem patientur, qui a justitia recesserunt.
verses.english: But the wicked will suffer their own condemnation, who have departed from justice.

verses.latin: Melius est enim non esse, quam vivere et impietatem operari.
verses.english: For it is better not to be, than to live and work wickedness.

verses.latin: Utique in malitia cogitantes, et impia loquentes, gravius punientur.
verses.english: Certainly, those who think evil and speak impious things will be punished more severely.

verses.latin: Spes enim impii, tamquam lanugo est, quae a vento tollitur, et tamquam spuma gracilis a procella dispergitur: et tamquam fumus a vento dispergitur,
verses.english: For the hope of the impious is like fluff which is taken away by the wind, and like thin foam that is dispersed by a storm: and like smoke dispersed by the wind,

verses.latin: et tamquam memoria hospitis unius diei praetereuntis.
verses.english: and like the memory of a guest who stayed a single day that quickly passes.

verses.latin: Justi autem vivent in perpetuum, et apud Dominum est merces eorum, et cura illorum apud Altissimum.
verses.english: But the just shall live forever, and their reward is with the Lord, and the care of them is with the Most High.

verses.latin: Ideo accipient regnum decoris, et diadema speciei de manu Domini: quoniam dextera sua protegct eos, et brachio suo defendet illos.
verses.english: Therefore they shall receive a kingdom of glory and a crown of beauty from the hand of the Lord: because with His right hand He will protect them, and with His arm He will defend them.

verses.latin: Sumpet enim zelum suum armaturam, et creaturam in ultionem inimicis.
verses.english: For He will take His zeal as armor, and creation as a weapon to avenge the enemies.

verses.latin: Induet pro lorica justitiam, et accipiet galeam judicii sinceri.
verses.english: He will put on justice as a breastplate, and will take the helmet of sincere judgment.

verses.latin: Sumet inexpugnabilem sanctitatem pro clipeo,
verses.english: He will take invulnerable holiness as a shield,

verses.latin: acceret autem severam iram pro gladio.
verses.english: and He will sharpen severe anger as a sword.

verses.latin: Congregabitur illi mundus adversus insensatos.
verses.english: The whole world will be gathered against the foolish.

verses.latin: Et ibunt exultantes in flagella sui.
verses.english: And they will go forth, rejoicing in their scourging.

verses.latin: Melior est ergo sterilitas cum virtute: quoniam virtutis memoria inmortalis est, quoniam et apud Deum et apud homines agnoscitur.
verses.english: It is better to be childless, if that keeps you virtuous, because virtue's legacy is immortal, and it is honored by both God and humanity.

verses.latin: Cum praesens est, imitatur Deum; et memoria illius, quoniam cum Deo est, et cum hominibus.
verses.english: When virtue is present, it imitates God. The memory of it is honored, because it is with God and with all humanity.

verses.latin: Cum praesens est, virtutem provocat ad certamen; coronat autem incorruptam victoriam aeternitatis.
verses.english: When virtue is present, it stirs up other virtuous deeds, and it crowns the incorruptible victory of eternity.

verses.latin: Prolem autem impiorum iniquitas velociter perdet: et progeniem inprobam, non habebit stabile fundamentum.
verses.english: The unjust are quickly destroyed by wickedness, and the offspring of the impious will not have a solid foundation.

verses.latin: Et si in tempore longo vixerint, pro nihilo habebuntur; et sine honore senectus illorum erit.
verses.english: Even if the wicked live a long life, they are considered to be nothing. Their old age is without any honor.

verses.latin: Et si cito decesserint, spem non habentes, nec in die iudicii consolationem.
verses.english: Even if they die quickly, they have no hope, nor comfort on judgment day.

verses.latin: Horrenda est enim malorum finis.
verses.english: The end of the wicked is horrific.

verses.latin: Quoniam et iustus, si morte praeoccupatus fuerit, in refrigerio erit.
verses.english: Even if the just die young, they will be at peace.

verses.latin: Senectus enim venerabilis est, non diuturna, neque annorum numero computabitur: sed sensus est hominis iustus, et aetas senectutis vita inmaculata.
verses.english: For honorable old age is not measured by the passing of time or the number of years, but by the wisdom of a just man, and old age is a blameless life.

verses.latin: Qui placuit Deo, dilectus est, et qui conversatus est cum peccatoribus, translatus est, ne malitia mutaret sensum ejus, aut ne fictio deciperet animam illius.
verses.english: The one who is pleasing to God is beloved, and the one who has lived among sinners is taken away, so that wickedness does not corrupt his mind, nor deception deceive his soul.

verses.latin: Fascinatio enim malitiae obscurat bona, et inconstantia concupiscentiae transvertit sensum sine malitia.
verses.english: For the fascination of evil obscures goodness, and the instability of lust perverts the mind without malice.

verses.latin: Perfectus in brevi explevit tempora multa: plena enim erat anima illius Deo placita, propter hoc festinavit rapere illum de medio iniquitatum.
verses.english: Having become perfect in a short time, he lived a long life. Because his soul was pleasing to God, God hurried to take him from the midst of wickedness.

verses.latin: Populi videntes et non intelligentes, nec ponentes in cordibus suis: quoniam gratia ejus et misericordia in sanctis ejus, et visitatio in electis ejus.
verses.english: The people see, but they don't understand, nor do they take it to heart. God's grace, mercy, and concern are with His holy ones, His chosen ones.

verses.latin: Qui iustus moritur, in refrigerio erit.
verses.english: He who dies justly is at peace.

verses.latin: Sensi et hoc, quod bona sit sapientia, et operatus sum in vita: et veni post illam, et eram zelator bonorum.
verses.english: I understood this, that wisdom is good, and I worked at it in my life. I pursued it, and I was zealous for good things.

verses.latin: Quoniam diligere justitiam, haec est perfectio sapientiae: et scire potentiam illius, radix est regni.
verses.english: For loving justice is the perfection of wisdom, and knowing His power is the root of the kingdom.

verses.latin: Si autem per provincias sedes, et per nationes, judicabis ea: reges illius admirabuntur eam.
verses.english: If you govern provinces and judge nations, the kings will admire wisdom.

verses.latin: Quoniam audierunt quod sapientia illius sit, et narraverunt illam: et qui audierunt, mirati sunt illam.
verses.english: Because they have heard about its wisdom, they have told others about it. And those who have heard it have been amazed by it.

verses.latin: Et si regnaverit, honorabitur in aeternum: cito enim transit gloria, et sapientia manet in aeternum.
verses.english: If wisdom reigns, it will be honored forever. For glory passes quickly, but wisdom remains forever.

verses.latin: Tunc stabunt justi in magna constantia adversus eos, qui se angustiaverunt, et qui abstulerunt labores eorum.
verses.english: Then the just will stand with great certainty against those who tormented them, and who took away their labors.

verses.latin: Vidéntes, turbabúntur timóre gravi, et mirabúntur in exspectatióne inopináta salútis.
verses.english: Seeing this, the wicked will be thrown into terrible fear, and they will be amazed at this unexpected salvation.

verses.latin: Dicéntes intra se, poeniténtes, et præ angustia spíritus geméntes: Hic est, quem hábui- mus aliquándo in derisum, et in similitúdinem contuméliæ.
verses.english: They will say to themselves, repenting, and groaning in anguish of spirit: "This is the one we once held up to ridicule and in a form of contempt."

verses.latin: Nos insensáti, vitam illíus æstimábamus insániam, et finem illíus sine honóre.
verses.english: We foolish ones considered his life to be madness and his end without honor.

verses.latin: Quómodo ígitur íste in fíliis Dei complutátus est, et inter sanctos sors illíus est?
verses.english: How, then, has he been numbered among the sons of God, and how is his lot among the saints?

verses.latin: Ergo errávimus a via veritátis, et justítiæ lumen non luxit nobis, et sol non est ortus nobis.
verses.english: Therefore, we have strayed from the way of truth, and the light of justice did not shine upon us, nor did the sun rise for us.

verses.latin: Oppréssi sumus a via iniquitátis et perditiónis, et ambulávimus vias difficíles, sed viam Domini ignorávimus.
verses.english: We have been oppressed by the way of wickedness and destruction, and we have walked difficult paths, but we have not known the way of the Lord.

verses.latin: Quid contúluit nobis supérbia? aut ditátió- nis jactántia quid prófuit nobis?
verses.english: What has pride done for us? Or what profit did the boasting of riches give to us?

verses.latin: Transiérunt ómnia illa tamquam umbra, et tamquam nuntius prætervolávit,
verses.english: All those things have passed away like a shadow, and like a messenger, they have flown away.

verses.latin: et tamquam navis, quæ per flúctum transit, cujus prætérita non inveniúntur, nec vestígium itineris ejus in kýlo flúctuum.
verses.english: And like a ship that passes through a wave, whose past is not found, nor the trace of its path in the wake of the waves.

verses.latin: Aut sicut avis, quæ transit per aérem, cujus nullum invenitur vestígium itineris, sed solus percussúra venti, et levi impúlsu agitátus æther transívit.
verses.english: Or like a bird that passes through the air, whose path leaves no trace, but only the striking of the wind, and the light impulse of the air, which it passed through.

verses.latin: Aut sicut sagítta, in córpore ejécta, dividens aérem, qui statim unitus est: ita et nos, natí, statim désiimus esse.
verses.english: Or like an arrow shot into the body, dividing the air, which immediately is united again: so also we, being born, immediately ceased to be.

verses.latin: Etenim exstincta est spes nostra, sicut púmili- na: et in hyeme dissipáta est quasi folium árboreum.
verses.english: Indeed, our hope is extinguished, like down: and in winter, it is scattered like a leaf from a tree.

verses.latin: Omnis enim vita nostra transívit sicut umbra, et non est régressus post mortem nostri: et signátum est obsignátum, quóniam nemo revértitur.
verses.english: For all our life has passed away like a shadow, and there is no return after our death: and it is sealed and confirmed, because no one returns.

verses.latin: Beáti ergo sunt justi, qui in Dómino sunt, et beáti, qui in Dómino speravérunt: et qui erant in illis, non respiciébant in vana, nec cognovérunt in vanitátem.
verses.english: Therefore, blessed are the just who are in the Lord, and blessed are those who have hoped in the Lord: and those who were in them did not look to vanity, nor did they know vanity.

verses.latin: Isti, in die visitatiónis suæ spléndebunt, et sicut carbúnculi, in ramis currént.
verses.english: These, in the day of their visitation, will shine, and like sparks, they will run in the branches.

verses.latin: Judicábunt natiónes, et dominabúntur pópulis: et regnábit Dóminus illórum in perpétuum.
verses.english: They will judge the nations, and they will rule over the peoples: and the Lord will reign over them forever.

verses.latin: Qui confídunt in eo, intélligent veritátem, et qui fidéles sunt in dilectióne, permanébunt in illo: quóniam grátia et pax est eléctis ejus.
verses.english: Those who trust in him will understand the truth, and those who are faithful in love will remain in him: because grace and peace belong to His elect.

verses.latin: Diligite iustitiam, qui iudicatis terram: sentite de Domino in bonitate, et in simplicitate cordis quaerite illum.
verses.english: All you who judge the earth: love righteousness, and feel the goodness of God, and seek Him with a simple heart.

verses.latin: Quoniam invenietur ab his qui non tentant illum, et apparebit eis qui fidem habent in illum.
verses.english: He is found by those who do not test Him, and He will appear to those who have faith in Him.

verses.latin: Perversae enim cogitationes separant a Deo: probata autem potestas arguit insipientes.
verses.english: Evil thoughts separate you from God. But the power of God will expose the wicked.

verses.latin: Quoniam in malevolam animam non introibit sapientia, nec habitabit in corpore subdito peccatis.
verses.english: For wisdom will not enter a hateful soul, nor will it dwell in a body held in sin.

verses.latin: Spiritus enim sanctus disciplinae effugiet fictum, et auferet se a cogitationibus quae sunt sine intellectu, et reprobabitur a superbia.
verses.english: The Holy Spirit of discipline will flee from what is fake, and will remove Himself from thoughts that lack understanding, and He will be rejected by the proud.

verses.latin: Quia procul est a superbia, et mendacium nequaquam sustinebit.
verses.english: Because wisdom is far from pride, and it will never embrace a lie.

verses.latin: Sapiens enim disciplinae, et intellegens cordis, fugiet iniquitatem.
verses.english: The wise, disciplined, and understanding person will flee from wickedness.

verses.latin: Quoniam spiritus sanctus disciplinae fugiet fictum, et auferet se a cogitationibus quae sunt sine intellectu, et reprobabitur a superbia.
verses.english: For the Holy Spirit of discipline will flee from what is fake, and will remove Himself from thoughts that lack understanding, and He will be rejected by the proud.

verses.latin: Spiritus enim sanctus disciplinae fugiet fictum, et auferet se a cogitationibus quae sunt sine intellectu, et reprobabitur a superbia.
verses.english: The Holy Spirit of discipline will flee from what is fake, and will remove Himself from thoughts that lack understanding, and He will be rejected by the proud.

verses.latin: Fundamentum ergo sapientiae timere Deum: intellectus vero bonorum est, observare legem Dei.
verses.english: The beginning of wisdom is to fear God. To understand the good is to obey the law of God.

verses.latin: Et regnum iustitiae sanctificatio et gloria ejus: et finis ejus vita sancta.
verses.english: The reign of righteousness is holiness and His glory; and its end is a holy life.

verses.latin: Si ergo diligitis sedes, reges, et sceptra, diligite sapientiam, ut in aeternum regnetis.
verses.english: If you love thrones, rulers, and scepters, love wisdom, so you may reign forever.

verses.latin: Quid enim citius quam sapientia, et operatur omnia?
verses.english: For what is quicker than wisdom, which does all things?

verses.latin: Et si virtus diligitur, hujus opera sunt virtutes: sobrietatem enim, et prudentiam docet, et iustitiam, et fortitudinem, quibus nihil est in vita hominum utilius.
verses.english: And if virtue is loved, these virtues are the works of wisdom. It teaches temperance, prudence, justice, and fortitude; nothing is more useful to men in life.

verses.latin: Si autem multam experientiam desiderat aliquis, scit praeterita, et de futuris aestimat.
verses.english: If anyone desires extensive experience, wisdom knows the past, and she estimates what is to come.

verses.latin: Novit versutias sermonum, et solutiones argumentorum: signa et monstra antequam fiant, novit.
verses.english: It knows the cunning of speech, and the answers to arguments. She knows signs and wonders before they happen.

verses.latin: Proposui ergo hanc mihi, et vitam, et bonum, et divitias, et non comparavi illi lapidem pretiosum.
verses.english: I therefore determined to take her as my life, and my good, and riches; and I did not compare her to any precious stone.

verses.latin: Quia praecessit me omnia bona, et venit mihi cum omni bonitate.
verses.english: Because she precedes all good things and comes to me with every good thing.

verses.latin: Omnia vero mihi simul venerunt cum illa, et innumerabilia bona per manus illius.
verses.english: All good things came to me together with her, and countless blessings through her hands.

verses.latin: Et gaudebam in omnibus, quoniam haec sequebatur me.
verses.english: And I rejoiced in them all, because she followed me.

verses.latin: Ignorabam quod horum omnium mater esset: ego enim sine fictione didici, et sine invidia communico, et abscondo illius divitias.
verses.english: I did not know that she was the mother of all these things. For I learned without pretense, and I share without envy, and I do not hide her riches.

verses.latin: Sine macula enim thesaurus hominibus: qui usi sunt, adepti sunt amicitiam Dei, propter disciplinae opera commendati.
verses.english: For she is a treasure to men without blemish; those who have used her have obtained the friendship of God, and are commended because of the works of discipline.

verses.latin: Propterea oravi, et datus est mihi sensus: invocavi, et venit in me spiritus sapientiae.
verses.english: Therefore I prayed, and understanding was given to me. I called on her, and the Spirit of wisdom came to me.

verses.latin: Et praeposui illam regnis et sedibus: et divitias nihil esse duxi, comparatione illius.
verses.english: And I preferred her to kingdoms and thrones, and I considered riches nothing in comparison to her.

verses.latin: Nec comparavi illi lapidem pretiosum, quoniam omnis auri, in comparatione illius, arena est exigua, et quasi lutum aestimabitur argentum ante illam.
verses.english: Nor did I compare her to a precious stone, because all gold, in comparison to her, is but a grain of sand, and silver will be considered as mud before her.

verses.latin: Super salutem et speciem dilexi illam, et proposui habere illam lucem, quoniam illuminatio ejus numquam exstinguitur.
verses.english: I loved her above health and beauty, and I determined to have her as my light, because her illumination is never extinguished.

verses.latin: Venerunt autem mihi simul omnia bona cum illa, et innumerabilis honestas per manus illius.
verses.english: But all good things came to me together with her, and endless blessings through her hands.

verses.latin: Ego quoque sum mortalis homo similis vobis, et de terra terrenus.
verses.english: I also am a mortal man, similar to you, and from the earth, earthy.

verses.latin: Et in ventre matris figuratus sum caro.
verses.english: And in my mother's womb, I was formed in the flesh.

verses.latin: Uno tempore natus sum, et eundem participabo discessum.
verses.english: Born at one time, I will share the same departure from life.

verses.latin: Omnibus autem ego clamabo: Deus sapientiae, et spiritus intellectus, veni in me.
verses.english: But I will call upon all: “God of wisdom, and Spirit of understanding, come into me.”

verses.latin: Paratus mihi est thronus regni, et dixi: Sponsa, et habitatio mea, et omnia opera illius.
verses.english: A throne of royalty is prepared for me, and I said: “Spouse and dwelling, and all of her works, are mine.”

verses.latin: Dedit mihi Deus scientiam veram, et scientiam sanctorum, ut sciam dispositionem saeculi, et virtutem elementorum,
verses.english: God gave me true knowledge, and the knowledge of the saints, so that I might know the order of the ages and the power of the elements,

verses.latin: initium et finem et medium temporum, mutationes vicium temporum, et conversiones aevi.
verses.english: the beginning, end, and middle of times; changes of the times, and the turnings of the ages.

verses.latin: Scio enim omnem rem manifestam et occultam, scio omnia quae sunt et ventura.
verses.english: For I know every manifest and hidden thing. I know all things that are and are to come.

verses.latin: Didicit me sapientia artifex omnium, ipsa enim me docuit.
verses.english: Wisdom, the maker of all things, taught me. For she taught me.

verses.latin: Est enim in illa spiritus, qui intelligit, sanctus, unicus, multiplex, subtilis, mobilis, disertus, impollutus, perspicuus, indemnis, amator boni, acutus,
verses.english: In her is the understanding spirit, holy, unique, multifaceted, subtle, mobile, eloquent, unpolluted, clear, unharmed, loving good, sharp,

verses.latin: liber, beneficus, humanus, stabilis, certus, quietus, omnipotens, omnia prospiciens, et penetrans omnes spiritus intelligentes, mundos, subtilissimos.
verses.english: free, beneficent, humane, stable, certain, quiet, all-powerful, overseeing all, and penetrating all intelligent spirits, pure, and most subtle.

verses.latin: Sapientia enim mobilior est omnium mobilium: propter suam puritatem omnia penetrat et pervadit.
verses.english: For wisdom is more mobile than all that is mobile. Because of her purity, she penetrates and pervades all things.

verses.latin: Est enim vapor virtutis Dei, et emanatio clara gloriae omnipotentis Dei: ideo nihil immundum in eam incurrit.
verses.english: For she is a vapor of the power of God and a clear emanation of the glory of the Almighty God; therefore, nothing impure enters into her.

verses.latin: Candor est enim lucis aeternae, et speculum sine macula Dei majestatis, et imago bonitatis illius.
verses.english: For she is the brightness of eternal light, and a mirror without blemish of God’s majesty, and the image of His goodness.

verses.latin: Et cum sit una, omnia potest: et in se permanens omnia innovat: et per nationes in animas sanctas se transfert, amicos Dei et prophetas constituens.
verses.english: And although she is one, she can do all things. Remaining in herself, she renews all things, and through the nations she transfers herself to holy souls, making them friends of God and prophets.

verses.latin: Amicitia enim illius bona est: et opera illius honesta sunt.
verses.english: For her friendship is good, and her works are honorable.

verses.latin: Docet enim continentiam et prudentiam, justitiam et virtutem: quibus rebus nihil est in vita utilius hominibus.
verses.english: For she teaches temperance and prudence, justice and virtue. Nothing is more useful to men in life than these things.

verses.latin: Si diligit quis justitiam, labores illius virtutes sunt: continentiam enim et prudentiam docet, quibus nihil est in vita hominibus utilius.
verses.english: If anyone loves justice, her labors are virtues. For she teaches temperance and prudence, than which nothing is more useful to men in life.

verses.latin: Si autem desiderat quis plurimam experientiam, scit praeterita, et de futuris aestimat: scit versutias sermonum, et solutiones aenigmatum: signa et prodigia scit antequam fiant, et eventus temporum.
verses.english: But if anyone desires much experience, she knows the past, and judges of the future. She knows the subtleties of words and the solving of riddles. She knows signs and wonders before they happen, and the events of the times.

verses.latin: Proposui ergo haec omnia mihi, et simul cum illa introduxi: quoniam opifex omnium docuit me sapientia.
verses.english: So, I proposed all these things to myself and brought them in together with her, because wisdom, the maker of all things, taught me.

verses.latin: Est enim in illa spiritus intelligens, sanctus, unicus, multiplex, subtilis, mobilis, disertus, impollutus, perspicuus, indemnis, amator boni, acutus, liber, beneficus, humanus, stabilis, certus, quietus, omnipotens, omnia prospiciens, et penetrans omnes spiritus intelligentes, mundos, subtilissimos.
verses.english: For in her is an understanding spirit, holy, unique, multifaceted, subtle, mobile, eloquent, unpolluted, clear, unharmed, loving good, sharp, free, beneficent, humane, stable, certain, quiet, all-powerful, overseeing all, and penetrating all intelligent spirits, pure, and most subtle.

verses.latin: Suscipiens enim sapientiam, cum bonis participabo, et probatus ei, qui a saeculo est, factus sum.
verses.english: For receiving wisdom, I will share with the good, and I will be approved by Him who is from the beginning.

verses.latin: Attingit itaque a fine usque ad finem fortiter, et disponit omnia suaviter.
verses.english: Wisdom reaches from one end of the universe to the other with strength and orders everything gently.

verses.latin: Hanc ego dilexi, et ex adolescentia mea exquisi
verses.english: I have always loved wisdom, seeking her since my earliest youth.

verses.latin: et volui sponsam mihi eam assumere, et amator factus sum formae illius.
verses.english: I desired to marry her. I loved her beauty.

verses.latin: Nobilitat generatio ejus cum Deo, et qui cum illa vivit, Deus diligit.
verses.english: Her lineage comes from God, and God loves those who live with her.

verses.latin: Est enim disciplina ejus ad immortalitatem, et memoria illius voluntas Dei.
verses.english: Her discipline leads to immortality, and remembering her means understanding God's will.

verses.latin: Ergo si diligitis thronos et sceptra, o reges populorum, honorate sapientiam, ut in saeculum regnetis.
verses.english: If you love thrones and scepters, O rulers of the people, then honor wisdom, that you may reign forever.

verses.latin: Quid est autem sapientia, et quomodo facta est? Narrabo, et non abscondam a vobis sacramenta Dei.
verses.english: What is wisdom, and how was she made? I will tell you. I will not hide the secrets of God from you.

verses.latin: Ego enim initium generationis ejus, et in cognitione Dei ordinata sum.
verses.english: I am the beginning of her generation, and I am ordered by the knowledge of God.

verses.latin: Scientiam ejus, et operationes ejus, annuntiabo, et non abscondam a vobis sacramenta Dei.
verses.english: I will proclaim her knowledge and her works, and I will not hide the secrets of God from you.

verses.latin: Ego enim cum illo, et omnia simul.
verses.english: I am always with Him, and I am one with Him in everything.

verses.latin: Ego mota sum a saeculo, et ab initio, et non deficiam, et non derelinquam illos.
verses.english: From eternity, I have existed, and I will never fail, nor will I abandon those who love me.

verses.latin: Cum autem scire coepi, quod bona esset, veni ad eam.
verses.english: When I came to know that wisdom was good, I sought her out.

verses.latin: Et cognovi quoniam non habebam illam nisi cum Deus daret eam: et hoc erat sensus rectus.
verses.english: I knew that I would not possess her unless God gave her to me. This was a proper and correct understanding.

verses.latin: Adolescens autem eram bonus, et animam bonam sum consecutus.
verses.english: Then, I was a good youth, and I acquired a good soul.

verses.latin: Immo vero cum essem bonus, veni ad corpus immaculatum.
verses.english: Indeed, though I was good, I came into an unblemished body.

verses.latin: Et sciens quoniam aliter non possem esse continens, nisi Deus daret, et hoc ipsum erat sapientiae, scire cuius donum esset: ad Dominum accessi, et deprecatus sum illum.
verses.english: And knowing that I could not be chaste unless God gave it, and that was wisdom itself—to know that it was a gift—I approached the Lord and begged Him.

verses.latin: Et dixi de corde meo: Pater, et Domine misericordiae, peto te, da mihi sapientiam, quae assistit tibi in throno tuo, et mecum est in operibus tuis:
verses.english: Then I said in my heart, “Father, Lord of mercy, I ask You, give me wisdom, which attends You on Your throne, and is with me in my works.”

verses.latin: et ne me projicias a filiis tuis.
verses.english: And do not cast me out from among Your children.

verses.latin: Ego enim servus tuus, et filius ancillae tuae: mitte in me sapientiam a sede sancta tua, et a throno gloriae tuae, ut mecum sit, et laboret mecum: ut sciam quid acceptabile est coram te.
verses.english: For I am Your servant, the son of Your handmaid. Send wisdom from Your holy seat and from the throne of Your glory, that she may be with me and labor with me, so that I may know what is pleasing to You.

verses.latin: Novit enim illa omnia, et intelligit: et deducet me in operibus meis sobrie, et custodiet me.
verses.english: For she knows and understands all things. She will guide me in my works prudently and will guard me.

verses.latin: Et erunt opera mea acceptabilia: et judicabo populum tuum juste, et ero dignus sedibus patris mei.
verses.english: Then my works will be acceptable, and I will judge Your people justly, and I will be worthy of my father's throne.

verses.latin: Quis enim hominum sciet consilium Dei? aut quis poterit cogitare quae voluntas Dei est?
verses.english: For who of men can know the counsel of God? Or who can understand what God wills?

verses.latin: Cogitationes enim mortalium timidae, et incertae provisiones nostrae.
verses.english: The thoughts of mortals are timid, and our plans are uncertain.

verses.latin: Corpus enim quod corrumpitur aggravat animam, et deprimit terrena inhabitatio sensum multa cogitantem.
verses.english: The body that decays weighs down the soul, and the earthly dwelling depresses the mind, which thinks much.

verses.latin: Et difficile conjecturamus quae in terra sunt: et quae in conspectu sunt, cum labore invenimus.
verses.english: And we can barely guess what is on earth, and what is before our eyes we find with difficulty.

verses.latin: Quae autem in caelis sunt, quis investigabit?
verses.english: But who can investigate the things in the heavens?

verses.latin: Voluntatem enim tuam quis sciet, nisi tu dederis sapientiam, et miseris sanctum spiritum tuum de altissimis?
verses.english: For who will know Your will unless You give wisdom and send Your Holy Spirit from the highest heavens?

verses.latin: Et sic correctae sunt semitae eorum qui in terra sunt, et homines didicerunt quae placent tibi.
verses.english: Then the paths of those on earth were set right, and men learned what pleases You.

verses.latin: Per sapientiam enim sanati sunt quicumque placuerunt tibi, Domine, a principio.
verses.english: For through wisdom, those who have pleased You, Lord, since the beginning, were healed.

verses.latin: Domine, Deus patrum et Deus misericordiae, qui fecisti omnia verbo tuo,
verses.english: O Lord, God of our fathers and God of mercy, You made all things by Your word,

verses.latin: et sapientia tua constituisti hominem, ut dominaretur creaturae, quae a te facta est,
verses.english: and by Your wisdom You formed man, so that he might govern the creatures that You made,

verses.latin: et temperaret orbem in sanctitate et justitia, et cumrectitudine cordis judicium judicaret:
verses.english: and that he might rule the world in holiness and justice, and judge with an upright heart:

verses.latin: da mihi sedium tuarum assistricem sapientiam, et noli me reprobare a pueris tuis:
verses.english: give me wisdom, who sits beside Your throne, and do not cast me out from among Your children:

verses.latin: quoniam ego servus tuus et filius ancillae tuae, homo infirmus et brevis intellectus, et minor judicii et legum.
verses.english: because I am Your servant and the son of Your handmaid, a man weak in mind and short of understanding, and lacking in the knowledge of Your laws.

verses.latin: Etenim si quis inperfectus fuerit inter filios hominum, ignorans tua, in sapientia erit habendus.
verses.english: For even if someone is perfect among the sons of men, without Your wisdom he will be held as nothing.

verses.latin: Nam etsi perfectus fuerit, ab eo sine sapientia in nihilum reputabitur.
verses.english: And even if he were perfect, without Your wisdom he would be regarded as nothing.

verses.latin: Ego autem tecum sapientiam et thronorum tuorum operatrix, et nescio facturas tuas, neque quid agere debeat.
verses.english: I have been with You, wisdom, and the worker of Your thrones, and I do not know Your works, nor what I should do.

verses.latin: Qui enim est homo qui invenire poterit cogitationem Dei? Aut quis poterit scire voluntatem Dei?
verses.english: For what man can know the counsel of God? Or who can understand what God wills?

verses.latin: Cogitationes enim mortalium timidae, et incertae providentiae nostrae.
verses.english: For the thoughts of mortals are fearful, and our understandings are uncertain.

verses.latin: Corpus enim quod corrumpitur, aggravat animam, et deprimit terrena inhabitatio sensum multa cogitantem.
verses.english: For the body that corrupts weighs down the soul, and this earthly dwelling depresses the understanding that contemplates many things.

verses.latin: Et difficile conamur, et laboramus, et malum habemus ad res praesentes.
verses.english: And with difficulty we strive, and we labor, and we have evil things in the present.

verses.latin: Quis enim sciet quae in caelo sunt, nisi qui de caelo est descendens?
verses.english: For who knows what is in heaven, except the one who comes down from heaven?

verses.latin: Et qui cognovit consilium tuum, nisi tu dederis sapientiam, et miseris spiritum sanctum tuum de altissimis?
verses.english: And who has known Your counsel, unless You have given wisdom, and sent Your Holy Spirit from on high?

verses.latin: Et sic correctae sunt semitae eorum qui sunt in terra, et didicerunt quae tibi placent, et per sapientiam salvati sunt.
verses.english: And thus the paths of those on earth were set right, and they learned those things that please You, and by wisdom they were saved.

verses.latin: Per hanc enim sanati sunt qui placuerunt tibi, Domine, a principio.
verses.english: For through this have those pleased You been healed, O Lord, from the beginning.

verses.latin: Nam etsi parvulus fuerit filius tuus, qui ad te venerit, habebit tecum sapientiam, et non spernit te.
verses.english: For even if the son who comes to You is small, he will have wisdom with You, and will not despise You.

verses.latin: Hunc enim scit Deus, et habitat cum sapientia, et per sapientiam regetur.
verses.english: For God knows this, and dwells with wisdom, and will be ruled by wisdom.

verses.latin: Sapientia justos conservavit, cum projicerentur impii: et evaserunt de morte justi.
verses.english: Wisdom protected the just, even when the wicked were being killed, and the just escaped from death.

verses.latin: Quae fugit impiorum iram, et in ipsis erroribus exstitit, justis viam monstrans.
verses.english: Wisdom escapes the wrath of the wicked and reveals the way of the just, even within their own errors.

verses.latin: Justos illam fugientes, suscepit: et in tentationibus non dereliquit, sed liberavit ab insidiis impiorum.
verses.english: She received the just who fled to her, and she did not abandon them during their trials, but delivered them from the snares of the wicked.

verses.latin: Et eduxit illam in via recta, et ostendit illi regnum Dei, et dedit illi scientiam sanctorum, et custodivit illam in laboribus.
verses.english: And she led them along the right path and revealed to them the kingdom of God, giving them the knowledge of the holy ones. And she kept them safe during difficult times.

verses.latin: Et laboravit illius iniquitatem, et non contempsit illam: sed recessit ab illis iniquis, cum judicium justorum veniret.
verses.english: She delivered the just from their wickedness and did not reject them, but turned away from the wicked when the judgment of the just came.

verses.latin: Et genus impiorum ingressum est in ira: qui cum dolentibus erant.
verses.english: And the race of the wicked entered into wrath, who were together with the sorrowing.

verses.latin: Quando auferrebatur multitudo mortuorum, sed non oblita est eos justitia Domini.
verses.english: When the multitude of the dead was being taken away, the justice of the Lord did not forget them.

verses.latin: Sed mercedem impiorum gentium reddens, et vindictam accipiens.
verses.english: But giving recompense to the wicked nations and taking vengeance.

verses.latin: Tunc enim conspexerunt mortales, quod pro peccatis suis passi essent: et cum illos, qui tunc videbantur, in vanum esse damnati.
verses.english: For then, the mortals saw that they were suffering for their sins and, when they were condemned to vanity, they saw that they had suffered in vain.

verses.latin: Nam, sicut pueri fugientes, in lucem, et abjecti, mortem, ita isti perierunt: et justi passionis mortis participes facti sunt.
verses.english: For, just as children fleeing to the light and being cast off by death, so these also perished, and the just became participants in the suffering of death.

verses.latin: In qua re, cum essent, illi viderunt, et cognoverunt justos esse, qui Deus contempserat.
verses.english: And in this thing, when they were, they saw and knew that the just were those whom God had rejected.

verses.latin: Propter quod et passionem eorum deriserunt: et in dolore mortis ejus contempserunt: et quid in eis erit finis.
verses.english: Because of this, they mocked their suffering and, in the pain of their death, despised them, as to what their end would be.

verses.latin: Tunc venient ad judicium suum, et timore conterrentur: et admirabuntur salutem injustorum.
verses.english: Then they will come to their judgment, and they will be terrified by fear, and they will marvel at the salvation of the unjust.

verses.latin: Qui enim ante non crediderunt in Deum, sed abierunt a Deo: qui enim sapientiam oderunt, et increpationes ejus contempserunt.
verses.english: For those who did not believe in God before, but turned away from God, those who hated wisdom and despised her reproofs.

verses.latin: Hi, cum essent, non invenerunt vias justitiae: et justitiae lucem non respexerunt, neque solis radiorum splendorem susceperunt.
verses.english: These, when they were, did not find the ways of justice and did not look upon the light of justice, nor did they receive the splendor of the sun's rays.

verses.latin: Qui perambulantes per viam iniquam, et vias perditas, nec viam Domini cognoverunt.
verses.english: They walked along the wicked way and the paths of destruction, and they did not know the way of the Lord.

verses.latin: Quid enim profuit illis superbia? aut quid illis divitiarum jactantia contulit?
verses.english: For what did pride profit them? Or what did the boast of riches bring to them?

verses.latin: Omnia illa transierunt, tamquam umbra: et tamquam nuntius praecipitans.
verses.english: All those things passed away like a shadow, and like a messenger hastening.

verses.latin: Et quasi navis transiens in mari, cujus nullum vestigium inveniri potuit, neque semita carinae in undis.
verses.english: And like a ship passing through the sea, whose trace could not be found, nor the path of the keel in the waves.

verses.latin: Aut sicut avis volans per aerem, cujus nullus est index transitum: sed vaporem tantum percussurae aeris, et impulsu alarum levi pervagans, postea nullum signum invenitur viae illius.
verses.english: Or like a bird flying through the air, for which there is no sign of its passing, but only the air that has been struck and the light, easy movement of wings, afterwards no sign of its path is found.

verses.latin: Aut sicut sagitta emissa in signum, quae divisit aerem, continuo consueta est, et illico rursum scindit, et nullam vestigii sui speciem inveniri potuit transitum.
verses.english: Or like an arrow shot at a target, which divided the air and then immediately cut it again, and no trace of its passage could be found.

verses.latin: Sic et nos, nati, continuo desivimus: et virtutis nullum signum potuimus ostendere, sed in malitia nostra consumpti sumus.
verses.english: So also we, when born, immediately ceased and could show no sign of virtue, but we have been consumed in our wickedness.

verses.latin: Exaudies, Domine, clamorem meum, et suscipe deprecationem meam.
verses.english: Lord, listen to my plea. Hear my prayer.

verses.latin: Ne intres in judicium cum servo tuo: quia non justificabitur in conspectu tuo omnis vivens.
verses.english: Don't bring your servant to judgment. No one alive can be found perfect in your sight.

verses.latin: Quia persequutus est inimicus animam meam: humiliavit in terra vitam meam.
verses.english: The enemy has pursued my soul and brought my life down to the dirt.

verses.latin: Collocavit me in tenebris, quasi mortuos saeculi: et moerore confectus est spiritus meus in me; in me turbatum est cor meum.
verses.english: He has put me in darkness like the dead, and my spirit is exhausted. My heart is deeply troubled.

verses.latin: Memor fui dierum antiquorum; meditatus sum in omnibus operibus tuis; in factis manuum tuarum meditabam.
verses.english: I remember the days of old; I reflect on everything you have done, and I meditate on the works of your hands.

verses.latin: Expandi manus meas ad te: anima mea sicut terra sine aqua.
verses.english: I stretch out my hands to you, my soul is like dry land.

verses.latin: Velociter exaudi me, Domine; defecit spiritus meus. Non avertas faciem tuam a me, et similis ero descendentibus in lacum.
verses.english: Answer me quickly, Lord; my spirit fails. Don't turn away your face from me, or I'll be like those who descend into the pit.

verses.latin: Auditam fac mihi mane misericordiam tuam, quia in te speravi. Notam fac mihi viam, in qua ambulem, quia ad te levavi animam meam.
verses.english: Let me hear of your mercy in the morning, for I trust in you. Make known to me the way I should walk, because I lift up my soul to you.

verses.latin: Eripe me de inimicis meis, Domine; ad te confugio.
verses.english: Rescue me from my enemies, Lord; I flee to you for refuge.

verses.latin: Doce me facere voluntatem tuam, quia Deus meus es tu. Spiritus tuus bonus deducet me in terram rectam.
verses.english: Teach me to do your will, for you are my God. May your good Spirit guide me on a straight path.

verses.latin: Propter nomen tuum, Domine, vivificabis me in justitia tua: educes de tribulatione animam meam.
verses.english: For your name's sake, Lord, revive me in your righteousness. Bring my soul out of trouble.

verses.latin: Et in misericordia tua disperdes inimicos meos, et perdes omnes qui tribulant animam meam: quoniam ego servus tuus sum.
verses.english: And in your mercy, destroy my enemies and destroy all those who afflict my soul, because I am your servant.

verses.latin: Quoniam magnifica sunt judicia tua, et inenarrabilia verba tua.
verses.english: Your judgments are magnificent, and no one can fully explain what you say.

verses.latin: Propter hoc indocti erraverunt: et illiterati putaverunt iniqua, et putaverunt justitias, quæ essent malæ.
verses.english: And so those who haven't learned have gone astray. The simpleminded have thought unjust things were just, and have considered evil things to be good.

verses.latin: Quoniam boni, et mali, in hoc sunt, quod judicium eorum.
verses.english: In this, the good and the evil are the same. Each will be judged on his own life.

verses.latin: In ea enim, quæ judicaverunt, in hoc errant, quoniam ignorantes Deum voluerunt justificare mala: et impietatem, et iniquitatem.
verses.english: They are wrong in the things they judge, for they don't know God, and they wish to call evil, sin, and unrighteousness just.

verses.latin: Propter hoc juste judicantes, iniquos punies: et in malis constitutos, quæ ipsi maluerunt.
verses.english: Because of this, you, O Lord, will justly punish the wicked, with the evils they have chosen.

verses.latin: Neque enim fugit te potentia tua: et ad te, qui es fortis, potestatem justitiam conjungis.
verses.english: For your power has not escaped you. You combine justice with your strength.

verses.latin: Cum enim justos judicaveris, existimans te non esse potentem, hoc est, non curas, cum tibi sit totius potentia.
verses.english: For if you judge the just to be powerful, it is not because you think they aren’t strong, or that you don’t care, since you have all power.

verses.latin: Ostendens potentiam tuam, qui justitiam judicas, et, dum contemneris, potentiam tua ostendas in his, qui non credunt perfectionem tuam.
verses.english: Showing your power to the ones who judge justly. When you are scorned, show your power to those who do not believe in your perfection.

verses.latin: Sed tu, dominator virtutis, juste judicas, et cum clementia gubernas nos.
verses.english: But you, Lord of power, judge justly and guide us with clemency.

verses.latin: Quoniam, cum volueris, potes, quoniam, cum volueris, potes, qui potentiae tuae virtutem non ignoras.
verses.english: Because when you want to, you can. For you know the power of your strength.

verses.latin: Et hoc est, ostendens justitiam tuam in his, qui non crediderunt te esse plenum virtutis, et malitiam eorum in his, qui ignorantes te fecerunt.
verses.english: And you show your justice to those who do not believe that you are full of strength, and their wickedness to those who have made you out to be ignorant.

verses.latin: Quoniam post hæc, cum ignoraverint, pœnabunt, et dolebunt.
verses.english: Because after this, when they are ignorant, they will be punished and will grieve.

verses.latin: Propter hoc in his, quæ impie vixerunt, tormentum dedisti: et vitas eorum, quibus displicuerunt.
verses.english: Because of this, you have given torment to those who have lived wickedly. You have given the lives that displease you.

verses.latin: Iniquitatem enim, et iniquum vitæ genera, detestati sunt.
verses.english: They detested iniquity and the wicked kinds of lives.

verses.latin: De quibus adhuc superest testimonium, quia in his, quæ passi sunt, judicaverunt; et in his, quæ displicuerunt, vindicati sunt.
verses.english: The proof of this is still present because they judged in what they suffered, and they were vindicated in what displeased them.

verses.latin: Et propter hoc iniqui, cum tormento erant, judicaverunt, existimantes se esse a te, quæ injuste egerant, non esse esse.
verses.english: And because of this, the wicked, with torment, judged, thinking they were from you, who unjustly did evil things.

verses.latin: In his enim, quæ peccaverunt, quæ putaverunt bona, in his iniquitatis pœnam susceperunt.
verses.english: For in the things they sinned in, which they thought were good, they received the punishment of iniquity.

verses.latin: Alios autem, et iniquos, qui etiam justi sunt, putaverunt dignos non esse cognitionis: et viis suis non ierunt, et malitia ipsorum despexerunt.
verses.english: But others, even the just, they thought weren't worthy of understanding and did not follow their ways. They looked down on their wickedness.

verses.latin: Hi enim et iniquos contempserunt, et juste damnati sunt.
verses.english: For they scorned the wicked, and were justly condemned.

verses.latin: Aliis autem, non supplicaverunt, et opera eorum non fuerunt cognita.
verses.english: To others, they didn't give offerings, and their works were not known.

verses.latin: Ipsi enim, quorum fuerant opera, perdiderunt, et in malitiam illorum confusi sunt.
verses.english: For they, whose works were evil, lost them, and were confused in their wickedness.

verses.latin: Et post hæc qui perierunt, cum dolore, sentientes ea, quæ gesserant, nunc confusi sunt.
verses.english: And after this, those who perished felt what they had done with sorrow and are now confused.

verses.latin: Judicium enim tuum, justum est.
verses.english: For your judgment is just.

verses.latin: Hoc est enim quod et impios deiecit: quia et bona quæ faciunt, contempserunt: et judicia tua, non credentes in ea.
verses.english: This is what cast down the wicked: because they scorned the good things they did, and they did not believe in your judgments.

verses.latin: Et propter hoc finis eorum terribilis est, et dolor ipsorum absque fine.
verses.english: And because of this, their end is terrible, and their grief is without end.

verses.latin: Vanæ sunt enim omnes homines, in quibus ignoraverint Deum: et de bonis, quæ videntur, potuerunt non intelligere eum, qui est, neque per opera attendentes agnoverunt, quis esset artifex.
verses.english: Indeed, all people who do not know God are foolish. Although they see all the good that exists, they can not understand the One who is. They have not recognized the artisan, even by considering the work of creation.

verses.latin: Sed aut ignem, aut ventum, aut citatum ærem, aut gyrum stellarum, aut impetum aquæ, aut solem et lunam, rectores orbis, deos putaverunt.
verses.english: Instead, they worshiped fire, the wind, the swift air, the circle of stars, the violent water, or the sun and the moon, which they considered to be the rulers of the universe.

verses.latin: Quorum speciem si delectati putaverunt deos, sciant quoniam multo illis speciosiores sunt: quoniam et creator illorum dominus est omnium.
verses.english: If, because they were delighted by such things, they considered them gods, then let them know that there are things far more beautiful than those. The Lord, who created them, is also the Master of all creation.

verses.latin: Si enim et virtute, et effectu stupuerunt, intellegant ex illis, quia qui hæc fecit, fortior illis est.
verses.english: If they were astonished by the things they made, because of their power and effect, then let them understand that the One who created them is even more powerful.

verses.latin: A magnitudine enim speciei, et creaturæ, cognoscibiliter potuerunt in ea existere, qui est, et non viderunt.
verses.english: They could have known the One who is by means of these things, for they are evident, and they should have seen Him through the creation.

verses.latin: Sed neque hoc excusabiles sunt. Si enim tantum potuerunt scire, ut judicare sæculum, quomodo horum dominum non facilius invenerunt?
verses.english: However, they are not excusable for this. If they were capable of knowing the world well enough to judge it, how did they not more easily find the Lord of those things?

verses.latin: Miserrimi itaque sunt, et in mortuis spes illorum est: qui et dixerunt deos esse, quæ sunt manufacta, aurum et argentum, et artificiosa animalium simulachra, et lapidem inutilem, opera manuum.
verses.english: They are wretched, and their hope is in the dead. They say that the gods are things made by human hands: gold, silver, crafted statues of animals, useless stone—the work of human hands.

verses.latin: Qui si cum his vixerunt, bonum illud putaverunt, et cum illis, qui sunt mortui, speraverunt.
verses.english: If they live with such things, then they consider such things good, and place their hope in those things which are dead.

verses.latin: Mali autem sunt, et in his sperantes, et facti sunt non boni: et quoniam non viderunt, justitiæ vias, nec introierunt per vias justas.
verses.english: They are evil because they hope in these things, and they become bad. They have not seen the ways of justice, nor have they entered the paths of righteousness.

verses.latin: Sed neque justitiam didicerunt, neque bonum cognoverunt: nec perversum deum putaverunt, opera manuum.
verses.english: They have not learned justice, nor have they come to know what is good. They have considered the work of their hands to be God, but it is perverse.

verses.latin: Propter hoc super eos veniet in die visitationis irrisio.
verses.english: Because of this, mockery will come upon them on the day of judgment.

verses.latin: Melius est enim non esse, quam esse et impietatem gerere: et nescire Deum, quam nescientem vitam ignorare.
verses.english: It is better not to exist than to exist and commit impiety. It is better to not know God than to not know the life of one who does not know Him.

verses.latin: Deum autem quærentes, invenerunt eum: et non reliquerunt eum.
verses.english: Those who seek God, will find Him, and they will not abandon Him.

verses.latin: Nam illis non revelavit, nec ostendit, quæcunque sunt mala, ut et bonum scirent, et quæ eis obsisterent, et per quæ amplius lucem acciperent.
verses.english: He did not reveal to them, nor did He show them, what is evil, so that they would know what is good, and what things oppose them, and through which they will receive even more light.

verses.latin: Pulchriora enim sunt omnia opera illorum in hoc mundo, quam est spes illorum: et homines, et ipsi, et quæ desiderant.
verses.english: For all of their works are more beautiful in this world than their hope, as are the people themselves, and the things they desire.

verses.latin: Et ipsi, qui sunt in hoc mundo, moriuntur: et ideo horum, quæ sunt opera, vanitates, quæ semper eis sunt, et quibus semper sperant.
verses.english: Even those who exist in this world will die, and that is why these things are vanity. These are their works, always with them, in which they always hope.

verses.latin: Misericordiam enim et gratiam impetrant, quoniam ab his abstinuerunt.
verses.english: They will obtain mercy and grace because they have abstained from these things.

verses.latin: Vaniloquum est enim et inane simulacrum, et in maledictionem opera, et initium fornicandi, et corruptio vitae.
verses.english: It is vanity to have idols, and the making of them is an act of destruction. The beginning of a spiritual death, and the true source of life's corruption.

verses.latin: Non enim fuerunt, neque erunt: propter quod visitatio illis subita veniet.
verses.english: These idols are not real, and they will not last. Therefore, a sudden judgment will come upon all who trust in them.

verses.latin: Quid enim? Cum pater in dolore laborans, statuam sine anima formavit manu sua, et vocabit illam imaginem, nullam formam habentem?
verses.english: For what is the point of a father, working through the pain of his labor, shaping an idol without a soul, a worthless image?

verses.latin: Sed opera illius mortua sunt, et ipse cum his quae fabricavit: cum hoc qui fabricavit.
verses.english: But the works of such men are dead, and they themselves, together with those they make—they are all dead together.

verses.latin: Pro eo quod simul erraverunt, et cum his qui dicunt ea, simul et speraverunt in mortuis.
verses.english: They stray together, and those who praise these idols hope in the dead.

verses.latin: Pro eo igitur quod digni sunt, et haec eis accidunt: et hoc est quod ipsi dicunt, Deos non esse bonos, et viventes tantum
verses.english: Therefore, because they deserve it, these things happen to them. They also say, “These idols are not good, nor are they alive, for they cannot see us, nor can they hear us, nor can they think, nor can they move.

verses.latin: et quod vident, non vident, neque audiunt, neque sciunt.
verses.english: They say, “We are the masters of our own fates.

verses.latin: Item autem neque sciunt, neque possunt.
verses.english: They say, “We are the masters of our own fates. Each man can live his life.”

verses.latin: Et sculptiles eorum, venti sunt: et haec iniqui nomine vocant dii.
verses.english: Their idols are but wind. And such wicked men call these idols gods.

verses.latin: Item qui in navibus eunt per mare, et cum tempestatibus laborant, et clamantes pro lignis, clamant ad simulacra ligneos.
verses.english: Those who sail on ships across the sea, and who labor in storms, calling out to wood, call out to wooden idols.

verses.latin: Qui factum est initium mali, et causa erroris, et causa discordiae.
verses.english: This is how evil began, and why men go astray, and why there is discord.

verses.latin: Quid enim? Quod fecerunt, bonum, et quod dixerunt, nihil est.
verses.english: For what is it? That which they have made is not good, and that which they have said is nothing.

verses.latin: Deus enim odibilis est impius, et impietas illi pariter abominabilis.
verses.english: For God hates the ungodly, and the ungodliness of men is similarly abominable to Him.

verses.latin: Ideo abominabilia erunt simul impius, et impietas ipsius.
verses.english: Therefore, the ungodly will be abominable, and the ungodliness of the ungodly will be as well.

verses.latin: Propterea iniquorum et opera, et ipsi ad poenam sunt.
verses.english: Therefore, the works of the wicked are a punishment for them.

verses.latin: Quoniam ergo iniqui, putaverunt habere Deum malum, et iniqua operati sunt, et iniqua digna morte, dicentes: Non existent, neque vitam, et putaverunt impios Deum esse.
verses.english: Because the wicked have thought that God is evil, and have done wicked deeds, and are worthy of death, they say: “There is no life.” And they thought the wicked should be God.

verses.latin: Quoniam hi qui faciunt talia, digni sunt, ut poenam habeant, et qui putant Deum non esse, non sunt.
verses.english: Those who do such things are worthy to be punished, and those who think there is no God, are not.

verses.latin: Mali enim opera, et verba impia, et vita mala, et haec praebent hominibus malum.
verses.english: For the wicked do wicked deeds, speak impious words, and live wicked lives—and these things will cause harm to men.

verses.latin: Quoniam existimaverunt per ignem, Deos esse, et viderunt eos ad tempus mori, et cum flante vento, consumentur: et putaverunt quod solus ignis, Dominus est universi.
verses.english: Because they thought fire was God, and they saw it die for a while, and then when the wind blew, it would burn up: and they thought that only fire was the Lord of all things.

verses.latin: Et ignem, et ventum, et celerrimum spiritum, et circulum stellarum, et aquam impetuosam, et solem, et lunam, rectores esse mundi.
verses.english: They considered fire, wind, the swift spirit of the air, the circle of the stars, raging water, the sun, and the moon to be the rulers of the world.

verses.latin: Quorum si speciem amant, putaverunt Deos esse: quos vident operari.
verses.english: If they loved their beauty, they thought they were gods: those who they saw working.

verses.latin: Quos si amant, ut operantibus, sciant quia multo meliores sunt: horum enim auctor, pulchritudo enim illorum, et creatura, in his qui operantur: et ut videntur, non in his qui operantur.
verses.english: If they loved these, they should have known that these are far better: for their creator is beauty itself, and that which is created is found in what is being worked: and what they see is not in those who do the working.

verses.latin: Sed neque hi excusantur: neque enim et per haec, putaverunt Deum agnoscere, et in illis qui operantur, non consideraverunt quis est.
verses.english: But they are not excused: because they do not know God by these things, and in those who do the working, they have not considered who He is.

verses.latin: Sed fortasse et paululum errantes, ignoscuntur: illi enim forte Deum desiderantes, et volentes invenire, non erraverunt in illis quae vident.
verses.english: Perhaps those who wander a little are excused: for they desired God, and wanted to find Him, they did not err in the things they see.

verses.latin: Sed neque hic: quoniam ipsi quaerentes, et investigantes, ad Deum inveniendum, in operibus illius errant.
verses.english: But neither do these men know, because they seek, investigate, and err in His works, when searching for God.

verses.latin: Velut enim si amatores, et per hoc facta, viderunt, et ipsi non crediderunt, quoniam illa quae vident, neque sunt, neque sunt: velut si ipsi operantur, velut et spiritus eorum.
verses.english: For, like lovers, they see the works and they themselves do not believe, because those things which they see neither are, nor exist. If they work, so does their spirit.

verses.latin: Vere stulti sunt omnes homines, in quibus non est scientia Dei, et qui ex bonis visibilibus non potuerunt intelligere eum, qui est, neque operibus agnoverunt, qui erat.
verses.english: Truly, all men are fools who lack the knowledge of God, and who, from visible goods, were not able to understand Him Who is, nor by their works did they recognize Who He was.

verses.latin: Sed aut ignem, aut ventum, aut citatum aerem, aut gyrum stellarum, aut nimiam aquam, aut solem et lunam rectores orbis, deos putaverunt.
verses.english: Instead, they have considered fire, wind, the swift air, the circle of stars, excessive water, or the sun and moon, the rulers of the world, as gods.

verses.latin: Quorum speciem si delectati putaverunt deos, sciant quod multo speciosiores sunt hi, quam illi. Quoniam et splendor illorum et species, et cursus illorum, et motus illorum, in potestate illorum sunt.
verses.english: If they, delighted by their beauty, thought them gods, let them know that these things are much more beautiful than those things. For their splendor, their beauty, their course, and their movement are in the control of God.

verses.latin: Sed nec ipsi iterum sunt digni venia. Si enim tantum potuerunt scire, ut possent æstimare sæculum, quomodo ejus Dominum non facilius invenerunt?
verses.english: But even they are not worthy of forgiveness. For if they were able to know so much that they could estimate the age of the world, how did they not more easily find its Lord?

verses.latin: Sed et illi in hoc excusabiles sunt. Fortasse enim errantes Deum quærunt, et volentes eum invenire.
verses.english: But even they are excusable in this. For perhaps, though wandering, they seek God, and desire to find Him.

verses.latin: In ipsis enim operibus ejus conversantes, investigant, et specie falluntur, quoniam videntur bona. Sed nec iterum digni sunt venia.
verses.english: For conversing with His works, they investigate and are deceived by appearance, because they seem good. But again, they are not worthy of forgiveness.

verses.latin: Si enim tantam habuerunt notitiam, ut potuerunt examinare sæculum, quomodo citius ejus Dominum non invenerunt?
verses.english: For if they had so much knowledge that they could examine the world, how did they not more quickly find its Lord?

verses.latin: Misera autem vita illorum est, et inter mortuos spes illorum: qui posuerunt in his spem, qui facti sunt opera manuum hominum, aurum et argentum, artificiose factum, et similitudinem bestiæ, aut lapidem inutilem, operis antiqui.
verses.english: But their life is miserable, and their hope is among the dead, those who place their hope in things made by human hands, gold, silver, skillfully made, and the likeness of beasts, or a useless stone from an ancient work.

verses.latin: Aut si fortasse lignarius dolavit lignum, et polivit diligenter, et deinde projecit illud in usum. Labor autem illius ad saturitatem vitæ, et artifex ejus in opere suo.
verses.english: Or perhaps a woodworker has carved wood, polished it carefully, and then cast it aside for use. But his labor is for the fullness of life, and the craftsman is in his work.

verses.latin: Miser est autem in his, qui posuit in mortuis spem, et qui vocavit mortuos deos: quia nec vivus, nec sanctus, nec verum vidit.
verses.english: But miserable is he who places hope in the dead and calls dead things gods; for he has seen neither the living, nor the holy, nor the true.

verses.latin: Simul enim operantur injusta, et opera eorum, et dolores eorum, et cogitationes eorum in vanum. Quoniam statua idolis facta, est initium fornicationis, et inventio illorum corruptio vitæ.
verses.english: For they act unjustly at the same time, and their works, their pains, and their thoughts are in vain. Because an idol statue is the beginning of fornication, and their invention is the corruption of life.

verses.latin: Neque enim fuerunt ab initio, neque erunt in perpetuum. Quoniam supervacua vanitas, et iniquitas illa est.
verses.english: For they were not from the beginning, nor will they be forever. Because that vanity is a useless emptiness and iniquity.

verses.latin: Mors enim per ambitionem introivit in orbem terrarum: et experiuntur eam qui ex parte illius sunt.
verses.english: For death entered the world through ambition, and those who are a part of it experience it.

verses.latin: Inique enim agentes putaverunt, non cogitantes, quoniam in quo male egerunt, in eo etiam puniuntur.
verses.english: For acting unjustly, they thought nothing of it, not realizing that in the very things in which they have done evil, they are also punished.

verses.latin: Nam qui justi, putaverunt vitam brevem esse, et defuncti, et non suam vocem audierunt: sed hi, qui non sunt justi, cogitaverunt: nec scientes Dei mysteria, speraverunt mercedem justitiæ, neque judicaverunt palma immaculati animæ.
verses.english: For the just thought life was short, and they departed and did not hear their own voice; but those who are not just thought, and not knowing the mysteries of God, did not hope for the reward of justice, nor did they judge the prize of an immaculate soul.

verses.latin: Quoniam Deus creavit hominem inexterminabilem, et imaginem similitudinis suæ fecit illum.
verses.english: Because God created man to be inexhaustible, and He made him in the image of His own likeness.

verses.latin: Invidia autem diaboli mors introivit in orbem terrarum.
verses.english: But through the devil's envy, death entered the world.

verses.latin: Et experiuntur illam qui sunt ex parte illius.
verses.english: And those who are a part of it experience it.

verses.latin: Pro iustis et sanctis, qui in exilio fuerant, factus est mirabilis cibus, qui apparuit illis.
verses.english: A wonderful meal appeared for the righteous and holy ones who were in exile.

verses.latin: Ut, cum passi essent adversa, et hostibus utique punitis, gustarent dulcedinem vitae.
verses.english: So that, after they had suffered adversity and their enemies were punished, they could taste the sweetness of life.

verses.latin: Nam pro quibus illi, sicut ferae, inridentes, bestiarum modos ignoti.
verses.english: For that which the animals, who were not supposed to know the ways of men, were mocking.

verses.latin: Missi sunt in flagella, sed non in iram; et in brevi puniti, beneficii digni fuerunt.
verses.english: They were sent as a punishment, but not in anger. They were punished briefly, and were then found worthy of blessings.

verses.latin: Nam illi, qui timuerunt, obsequio et servitute erant; hi vero, non timentes, cruciabantur.
verses.english: For those who feared were in servitude. Those who did not fear were tormented.

verses.latin: Sicut illi, qui in tenebris, ita et hi, qui in ignorantia, erant in tenebris.
verses.english: Those who were in darkness, and those who were in ignorance, were both in darkness.

verses.latin: Nam sicut dormientes, ita et hi, dormiebant consopiti somno terribili.
verses.english: For as those who are asleep, so too were these who slept in a terrible slumber.

verses.latin: Sed non sic illos Deus perdidit; sed vagantes monuit, et, peccantes, prope se memorans virtutes.
verses.english: But God did not destroy those people. He warned the wandering, and, remembering His virtues, warned them.

verses.latin: Nam per quas passus est, ostendit se illis in salutem, et, vigilantes, cognoverunt, quia per quos tunc cruciabantur, hi erant et Deus.
verses.english: For through their suffering, He showed Himself to them for salvation. And, being awake, they knew that He, God, was with them at that moment.

verses.latin: Pro quo genus eorum, qui ante se erant, interierunt, propter bestias.
verses.english: For the sake of the people who came before them, they were killed by animals.

verses.latin: Pro eo, quod cogitaverunt, et impia et pessima, errantes; et, quam putaverant deos, hos et illos.
verses.english: They were led astray by their wicked and perverse thoughts, and thought those very things that they imagined to be gods.

verses.latin: Quorum finis est iniustus, et iniuria per eos, qui sunt.
verses.english: They ended in unjust suffering. And the harm was done through them who are.

verses.latin: Nam ignis, aut ferae bestiae, illis supervenientes, puniuntur; et vel pro illis, vel pro opere impietatis.
